structuralFindings.rationale: Ford exhibits a hybrid structure with multiple distributed AI units: (1) Latitude AI - a 550-person autonomous driving subsidiary headquartered in Pittsburgh with hubs in Dearborn and Palo Alto; (2) Ford Greenfield Labs in Palo Alto with ~300 researchers; (3) Ford Atlanta Research and Innovation Center (FARIC) focused on software and digital transformation; (4) Ford Research and Advanced Engineering with a dedicated Robotics and Artificial Intelligence Research team; (5) A skunkworks unit under Doug Field for affordable EVs. Each unit has distinct focus areas while drawing on central capabilities. The Ford+ restructuring that separated Model e (EVs), Ford Blue (ICE), and Ford Pro (commercial) represents classic structural ambidexterity.
structuralFindings.aiTeamStructure: Ford has multiple AI-focused organizational units: (1) LATITUDE AI: A wholly owned subsidiary (~550 employees) focused on hands-free, eyes-off automated driving technology. Led by CEO Sammy Omari, CTO Peter Carr, and President David Gollob. Headquartered in Pittsburgh with engineering hubs in Dearborn and Palo Alto. (2) FORD GREENFIELD LABS (Palo Alto): ~300 researchers, engineers, designers and scientists working on human-centered design and technology intersections. (3) FARIC (Atlanta): Focused on software-led connected vehicles, AI, and university research partnerships. (4) FORD INNOVATION HUB (Dearborn): 2.1M sq ft campus supporting 6,000+ employees across research labs, invention studios, and prototyping. (5) ROBOTICS AND AI RESEARCH TEAM: Part of Ford Research and Advanced Engineering, focused on sensors, machine learning, aerial robotics, and mobility devices. (6) SKUNKWORKS (EV Development): Led by Doug Field (ex-Apple, Tesla) focused on affordable EV development.

structuralFindings.investmentSignals: Latitude AI employs ~550 people from Argo AI acquisition. Ford Greenfield Labs has ~300 researchers. Ford Innovation Hub in Dearborn supports 6,000+ employees. BlueCruise has accumulated 50+ million miles of hands-free driving. Q3 2025 showed record revenue of $50.5B with $2.6B adjusted EBIT. Strong free cash flow ($4.3B in Q3, $5.7B YTD). $1B cost reduction target for 2025, another $1B planned for 2026. Company is 'systemically deploying AI across the entire industrial system' per Q3 2025 earnings call.

observableMarkers.reportingStructure: Latitude AI operates as wholly owned subsidiary with own C-suite (CEO, CTO, President). Doug Field as Chief Advanced Product Development Officer suggests AI/advanced tech reports to a product-focused executive rather than CIO/CTO. Ford Credit has Head of Non-Risk AI/ML and Gen AI reporting to Ford Credit CTO. Decentralized structure across Model e, Ford Blue, and Ford Pro divisions.
observableMarkers.resourceAllocation: Dedicated subsidiary for autonomous driving (Latitude AI). Separate innovation centers in Palo Alto, Atlanta, and Dearborn. Ring-fenced EV/skunkworks development under Doug Field. Strong cash position ($33B cash, $54B liquidity) enables continued investment.
observableMarkers.timeHorizons: Short-term: Deploying AI across industrial system, quality improvements, warranty process optimization. Medium-term: BlueCruise expansion and enhancement. Long-term: Hands-free, eyes-off-road automated driving via Latitude AI (5-10 year horizon).
observableMarkers.decisionRights: Distributed across divisions (Model e, Blue, Pro) and specialized units (Latitude AI, Greenfield Labs). Central R&D sets standards while subsidiaries/centers have operational autonomy.
observableMarkers.metrics: BlueCruise miles driven (50M+), quality improvement metrics, cost reduction targets ($1B/year), employee productivity, technician training effectiveness.

summary: Ford exhibits a Hybrid/Hub-and-Spoke (M4) model with Structural ambidexterity. The company operates multiple specialized AI units: Latitude AI (550 employees) for autonomous driving, Greenfield Labs (~300 researchers) for human-centered research, FARIC for software/digital transformation, and a Doug Field-led skunkworks for affordable EVs. The Ford+ restructuring that separated EV, ICE, and commercial divisions represents classic structural separation of exploration and execution. CEO Jim Farley frames AI primarily through a workforce lens, warning that AI will 'replace half of white-collar workers' while advocating that AI should 'supercharge' rather than replace essential economy workers.
